rules: Rule1: Either the food sample is contaminated, or the event poses a public health risk.
Rule2: In the event that the food sample has microbial growth, it has pathogen present.
Rule3: Assuming the food sample has pathogen present, then if the food sample is contaminated, it causes illness.
Rule4: The food sample has visual contamination or it has odor contamination.
Rule5: Whenever the food sample has odor contamination, it is not compliant.
Rule6: If the food sample has a critical violation, then it has a severe violation.
Rule7: Given that the food sample has improper storage, then if it is contaminated, it causes illness.
Rule8: Either the food sample has improper storage, or it has a temperature violation.
Rule9: In the case that the food sample has a temperature violation, it has a time violation.
Rule10: Should the food sample have a time violation, then it has microbial growth.
Rule11: If an event is inspection scheduled, then it poses a public health risk.
Rule12: Whenever an event is inspection completed, it is inspection scheduled.
Rule13: Provided that it is not true that visual contamination leads to non-compliance, then the food sample has a critical violation.
Rule14: In the event that it is false that a time violation implies contamination causes illness, then the food sample has a minor violation.
Rule15: If an event is not inspection completed, then the food sample is compliant.
Rule16: Whenever an event is not inspection completed, the event requires follow-up.
Rule17: Should an event not be inspection completed, then it is not the case that the event requires follow-up.
facts: Fact1: It is not true that the food sample has a severe violation.
Fact2: The food sample does not cause illness.
Fact3: It is not the case that the food sample has a minor violation.

question: An event poses a public health risk.
